review_title: Heart is in the right place
job_title: Digital Strategy Senior Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Despite many career ups and downs, I mostly love the people and culture at Accenture. They a progressive company that sets strong I&D goals and strives to create a great place to work. Part of consulting is constantly learning, developing new skills and getting new experiences. Work life balance is somewhat prioritized. I never work on vacations, but there are definitely grinding weeks. I think Accenture is always striving to be the best that they can be, even if they don't always get it right.
cons: It's a huge company and sometimes it's easy to feel a little lost, especially when your network leaves to go elsewhere. There are times when it gets exhausting to be constantly needing to become an expert in a new thing, whether you have any interest in it or not. There are always difficult clients and while leadership will mostly have your back when working with a difficult or unreasonable client, they will often side with the client to maintain good relationships.

pros:
Livable salary, ability to pay my bills, support my small and growing family.
Shower you with presents, free uber eats vouchers, free Accenture gear.
Lots of fun events, meet up opportunities, did I mention free food + gifts?
Apprenticeship program is great, but hard work as expected. Worth the experience. A very good "foot in the door" place to start your career in the tech field.
cons:
Did not adjust salary during inflation. I wanted to change my People Lead many times but no one helped me, not even my HR partner.
Feedback is one way, there's no way to give feedback to higher ups who don't do well, this leads to power plays and blackmail.
They shower you with a lot of gifts to keep you loyal and hope you don't ask too many questions, but they don't pay you much at all.
If you want to know your actual salary, then add about $30k or way more to your Accenture salary to calculate your worth.
Project based work is stressful, you never know who you're going to work with. Some people are amazing, and some people are purely the worst. It's a rollercoaster ride for sure.
There seemed to be like an air of preppy college faux positivity and political correctness as a cover up for things that can be potentially harmful. If you can see right through it then good for you.
Take advantages of the resources and then move on to better opportunities, Accenture is not known for paying well. The apprenticeship and entry level arena is like playing Survivor, good luck.
I passed the Apprenticeship and I'm being paid $60k while there is no increase for inflation. This is a good "foot in the door" job. But I have to tell you all that, YOU ARE WORTH IT! And Accenture will keep you complacent with $40 UberEats voucher,  "promote" you with a small pay raise that's still way under market value, and a free branded sweatshirt and water bottle every few months. If you're happy with an entry level $60k salary in the tech field, then you should take it just to pay the bills, level up like crazy, apply to other companies, and negotiate 6 figure salaries. Oh yeah another con, you need to find your own project, if you are not on a project, you are considered "benched", so basically you are applying for jobs while you have a job. After a year, it becomes ridiculous, so take your 1 year experience and love yourself, and go where they value you more.

job_title: Tech arch delivery analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- A friendly place full of well-meaning people all around.

- There are plenty of events to get to know the communities around you. 

- You can make meaningful friendships here at the Analyst level and possibly beyond.

- Your success for the most part is all about "showing up." Don't be afraid to take on new tasks EVEN if you don't know the subject well.

- You don't need to learn everything in your first year to do extremely well. As a matter of fact, pick 1 or 2 things, and get really good at them. That's the best way upward at ACN.

- Networking your way around. It is company culture, DO IT!

- Managers tend to be super invested in the well-being and happiness of the client.

- Work-Life Balance(I have heard that I got lucky).

- Just like everything else, your happiness here will depend on two things:
The amount of effort you put in: Showing Up!
The way you choose to interpret your results: Your definition of doing well.
It would also help if you avoid comparing yourself with others.

- There is a certain level of freedom that comes with being a consultant. This thin veil where everyone at your clients recognizes that "you are part of their team but you are not one of them". That can be a blessing and a curse. A blessing as people will avoid over stepping. A curse, depending on your team, you may be constantly reminded of that. But it can be liberating! Say your contract says 8 hours... you can walk in at 9 and leave at 5p. Some leave at 4p-430p. While the company's actual FTEs may have to work 9-10 shifts or more.
cons:
- It is a HUGE organization and it is growing. You will get lost trying to learn or take in everyone's advice. You will need to fine-tune your hearing to take in some and be okay with letting the rest go.

- Pay at entry-level is up to par with the industry. I do believe L9 and above are underpaid by an astronomic margin which begs the question of why they stay(one of the pros)

- Your success can often be how loud you scream "Look at Me!"
Sometimes, I feel like I get too many opinions and not enough facts.

- Networking can be demanding, especially for introverts like me. Or maybe "I am just making excuses."

- Depending on your project, Work-Life Balance may be a myth.

pros:
1. Good opportunity to work with different clients and learn new technologies. 
2. Good work life balance (but majorly it depends on the project you are working on). 
3. After getting released from a project, you don't have to look for new projects. Projects with suitable roles/demands will contact you as a list is shared with them of people on bench. 
4. You may get Onsite opportunities(not all projects) if you stick with a project for some time and perform well.
cons:
1. Compensation - it is as per the market standard but if you stay in the organization for very long then you will definitely notice a huge gap in the compensation with peers who has switched multiple times. In short there's no huge benefit of staying loyal. However, Fiscal year 2021-22 they have given good hikes for reducing the attrition.
2. Being a Service based company, with every new project you need to start from zero and perform well and once the project is over you need to start over. This is a vicious cycle which may impact your appraisal cycle if you get rolled off untimely as in the new team/project you need some time to attain that level of mastery.

review_title: Very Shady and  Sketchy Company Culture
job_title: Senior Analyst in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Opportunity to work at client companies such as Google, Facebook...etc. 
(or you could also be forced into working at a client that is undesirable)
cons:
- Very Shady and Sketchy Company Culture both toward employees and toward clients 

- accenture (HR) forces employees to sign documents to give up their benefits rights, and most employees don't even realize that they are signing (the document was dressed as something else), as this is also against the law, we had to file official complaint to the city government to get things fix.

- Shady, impolite middle management team (mostly indians), with no integrity;  treats employees like slaves, employees are constantly treated with no manner, and with no respect.

- Employees constantly being asked to work overtime after work hours (another employee said he was held at client site past 11pm daily) and sometimes even on weekends, while denied any rightful compensation that was supposedly promised (his was told by his manager to log in the system he never work over-time). 
- Every time I was at the accenture office, i just hear multiple different employees complain about their poor treatment by the company or at their project. 

- Although, it was communicated that employees have the choice to accept or decline projects, however, a lot of employees are forced into undesirable projects not at-will, and will be retaliated against if employees decline the project. 

- Company retaliates when employees brings forward issues or complaints, retaliation in every possible way (eg. denial of bonuses, fake/poor performance review regardless of actual performance) 

- accenture hides information from client, accenture has access to much of client's data, when they discovered any new source or information, they hide and withheld those info from the client for their own benefits (and these are actually client's own data), and accenture refused to share any role info to client's other vendors/contractors outside of accenture. 

- Employees are constantly reminded to up accenture's benefits as the first priority even at the expense of the client's, or even if it harms the client. 

- There are so much politics and teams would complain and escalate complaints against each other, it's a hostile environment where collaboration is difficult.

- The list could go on and on... accenture is really a discouraging and depressing place to work at!

job_title: Applications Development Analyst in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Accenture is an amazing company to work with.
Work-life balance - Now, it depends on what you look at when I say Work-life Balance. Are you looking for 9-6 job? Or you want to just work for 9 hours, or you have constraints due to other activities you do at home, like take care of new and old, have pets, you are the superwoman or superman of the house. Well, Accenture give you opportunity for all of the above. But, then you should be okay to see someone else going ahead or getting other opportunities, as they show more flexibility (Don't get me wrong here). What I mean to say is, Accenture supports all the above, but you need to discuss with your manager and see what works for you.
cons: International relocation - I always thought if it is a big company, chances of moving out are really big. But, I was totally wrong. And those who aspire for onshore, I would say, try to get it on your own. That would be easy compared to year after year discussion with your manager. In fact, your manager will change, and new manager will tell you that he is made aware of your aspiration only recently.

job_title: Applications Development Team Lead in Pune
pros: Has great cloud certification programs; sponsors all levels of AWS, GCP, Azure certifications and provides free training as well. Company greatly cares for employees pertaining to health - covers medical expenses for COVID, provides free vaccinations for employees AND their loved ones, and even provides counselling for mental well being. Provides WFH budget for buying desk and setup; ships laptops to employees' location. Apart from company benefits, one really gets to work with best people around the world. The friendly environment and diligent culture in workplace truly instills qualities that one needs to succeed in corporate life.
cons: One major gripe is that sometimes company commits many services to clients before consulting its employees, just to get projects. The team performing groundwork then has to deliver all the commitments, however unreasonable they may be, within strict timelines. It all depends on the client and people you work with.. In my experience there are those who make reasonable commitments then there are those who overcommit to client just to keep the project going. I had experience with both. Also, sometimes an employee can be stuck with a technology that isn't relevant anywhere but only to client. Employees can find themselves stuck working on technology that they may not wish to build career with; and these frustrations can lead to attrition.

pros:
You might like it, if you like feeling more competent than every level of management, at least that’s how Song was. 

You’re part of a community of 750K people +\-, and most support, including tech and HR, is self-serve, so you’ll feel a sense of accomplishment, after your problem gets solved by yourself or in 4 months when you finally can contact a real person if you didn’t figure it out.
cons:
Not getting paid on time, at the correct amount despite submitting pay sheets two days earlier than the pay period ends - every pay period - you estimate you last two days of work in the pay cycle. They’ll supposedly reimburse you, but good luck getting through their Byzantine systems of bots and FAQ sheets. 

Oh and they withheld my last paycheck way over the federal legal time. And then in typical fashion sent me checks they canceled. And then a direct deposit that wasn’t the right amount. At least I was paid, even if it was the wrong amount and 5 weeks late right?! I’ve never had this many problems getting a correct paycheck. 

It is evident from the corporate meetings and materials, they want you to feel like you matter, but the every day experience of the employee may leave you feeling that is a corporate platitude. It did me. 

Oh and don’t fall for the if you work hard and learn skills you’ll get promoted. I did and got promoted and no pay raise. I know others this happened to - either stepped up to the plate and/or got promoted and got a nominal raise like everyone at the appropriate time or maybe without a job when clients go bye-bye because I saw that a lot - more than any previous agency I worked for. By the way they bought so many ad agencies (ACN and two other companies keeping buying up agencies - I find this alarming. I also have seen so many big brands go in-house - methinks there is a correlation.

review_title: Try to get a higher level from the initial interview
pros:
-good benefit platform
-on time payment
-performance bonuses
-annual bonuses 
-well organized learning platform
cons:
Low and middle management in Accenture Romania are completely unaware of what their projects are about.

Hard to gain levels in the company, if you start from the bottom. Best way to receive a higher level is to quit and get hired again on a higher level. We had several cases of colleagues spending 2-3 years on the same level (12- the lowest) , quitting for 6 months and then returning on a higher one (10, 9, even 7). 
Everyone will just lie to your face. If you are part of a project with multiple middle managers (team leaders) , each and every one of them will have a different sorry on what is going on, none of them actually close to the truth. 

Internal HR department (because they also use 3rd party recruiting companies ) is a total disaster: They mix up positions and candidates, job opportunities, etc. It is impossible to get a clear answer to any question you might have. 

-If you prove you are an efficient employee, you will work for the entire team. Find your pace and do not worry about efficiency.

job_title: Tech Architecture Delivery Associate in Santiago
pros:
I have seen many times corporations gloat about their inclusiveness in the workplace only to see the headlines next month about some sort of abuse.

Here at Accenture I've actually felt included at every point by everyone, not on a corporate way but on a human one, everyone is helpful, nice, knowledgeable, etc.

The base pay is also pretty nice and it includes lots of benefits for employees, from flexibility to affiliations with enterprises which offer any kind of service (banks, insurance, gyms, etc.), you also have the right to an ergonomic chair.

Accenture has access to so many learning resources that I can't stress enough how good it is for learning and furthering your career. They pay for any course or certification I've ever wanted and more.
cons:
Sometimes the flexible workday is used to have you working more time than needed.

At least on my current project extra hours aren't easy to indicate, you need explicit permission from your manager to have them.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros:
- US MNC culture. People are polite and do hear your opinion (when they are in a good mood, that is).
- Management Consulting of Accenture is great. I've heard good stories about that vertical. Technical Consulting is usual service organization type.
- Project can be good, bad or extremely bad, depending on the vertical you are getting into. For instance, if it is Telecommunications, then expect rude bosses, low bonuses and crappy work; Banking is good, but comes with short shelf life; Healthcare & Insurance are going to be bureaucratic but with OK work. 
- Good company to travel abroad and around
- Salaries have become competitive lately due to high attrition
cons:
- Very watered down technical environment. Leadership and upper management are mostly non-techies so learn to explain your technical problems like you are explaining a 10 years old
- Kiss up and kick down culture, especially in lower ranks (below Senior Manager levels)
- As you climb up the corporate ladder, you'd be expected to work less technically, and more on sales and RFP (proposal) work
- Against all odds, if you stay techie and do less RFP work, promotions will be few and far between
- Manager/boss is everything in Accenture. Keep him impressed.
- Accenture HRs are all powerful entities. Never. Ever. confront an HR.
- Appraisals, promotions and moderations are all fixed. Managers target who is going to be promoted and who is not, regardless of your good work. Bonuses, however, depends on your work, but in big accounts they'll be rationed.
- Middle management in tech, especially in countries like USA and UK, are mostly south asians. They have their own code of life and work. Familiarize yourself with those if you need to rise.

pros: Accenture solves some of the biggest problems for the largest companies in the world with some of the smartest people I’ve ever met. The company takes care of its performers financially, and genuinely makes people feel appreciated and cared for, which is something other firms pay lip service to but fail to execute.
cons:
With 600,000+ professionals globally, there are some bad teams, bad managers, and bad projects. For the people who get stuck with one of those, Accenture can be a real challenge. 

Also, over the past few years Accenture has become extremely stingy when it comes to investing in trainings and pet projects — Most Managing Directors I know can’t even get $4,000 a year for investing in creating new offerings or special projects.

job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst in Kuala Lumpur
pros: Work Balanced. HR is supportive. The salary is not quite basic. Not high compared to the market.
cons: I have been working for 4 years in Accenture Malaysia. What I observe is most of the high management roles are taken by Malaysia Chinese. I would say, Malaysia Chinese is very competitive and they don't want the other race such as Malaysia Indian, Muslims or expats to replace their roles when they get the promotion. Instead, they would nominate another Chinese. This is just a personal view from me because I used be in the competition that way when my performance was always on top for the Lead role but one day, very suddenly without any notice, it was taken by an unknown selfish person. Overall, if you want to find a normal place with a normal job and live in peace, this is a choice for you, but do not expect a high level in the management system.

pros: - Opportunity to work in interesting projects at interesting clients
cons:
My company was acquired by Accenture, so I merged into this new organization. I had to quit because of an emigration. A few findings: 

- Simply too big and complex an organization
- Very burocratized: there are forms, regulations and automated email warnings for literally everything
- There is no end-to-end ownership across teams and trust me, you would like a case manager for anything that cannot be solved by your HR partner or the operational helpdesk directly
- It´s a global organization, but it´s ultra-hard to get things done between countries
- Even the off-boarding evaluation form is standardized into a multiple-choice, and did not fit my situation. If you leave the company because of an emigration, why do you still need to provide 2 additional reasons? Come on.

pros: Total Rewards - Offers industry leading compensation package Unlimited Training Opportunities - Massive selection of trainings and certifications Flexible Work Schedule - Offers great flexibility in terms of location and schedule
cons: Client Dependency - Flexibility on schedule and location depends largely on the client and industry Trainings are to be taken on top of regular work Leadership are hit or miss - If you somehow belong to a group where leaders are not people oriented or are boomers, then goodluck.

pros: Loved my time at Accenture - learned so much and had the opportunity try different things. I felt very well supported when I had a post-covid wobble. Work-life balanced improved immensely since I joined in 2010.

review_title: Awesome for juns and senior managers
pros:
If you are a junior it is a great place to start your carer.

It is easy to quickly grow up to the Manager position at a senior level and receive benefits such as good bonuses for KPIs, mobile phones, the latest MacBook, and travel.

Variety of different tech stacks and projects, you can change projects and stacks and stay in the same working environment.

Awesome company culture and values, every person counts, you will never face aggression, bad attitude or any cultural problem there.
cons:
Underpayment by local markets, Accenture payments are usually 15-30% less than other similar companies.

Some people are stuck in mid-levels and skipped in promotions because the procedure is not straightforward and depends not on your results but on how you communicate with your managers. 

When you reach the Manager position you will probably face a "Glass ceiling" and not will be promoted to the next levels (but still can increase your paychecks)

review_title: Good company lots to learn and do
pros:
You make your career
As you get more senior you control what work you do
People are high caliber and all are driven
If you are on the right projects the work is extremely interesting
Access to experiences that people only get 15-20 years into a regular career (i.e. board level presentations, advisory to senior management at F500 companies etc..)
Learn 3 years with in 6 months 
It's a great place to start or grow your career as you learn a ton but it takes work to understand how to thrive in the machine if you do, your career will be fast tracked by at least 10 years if you stay or if you leave.
cons:
High paced so you a lot of hours initially to ramp up to others pace
Expectation to do firm initiatives outside work hours 
At times disjointed promo expectations, that are more based on who you know rather than what you did
Work can be boring if you are on a large implementation for years (need to be strong and push to get off, might take some heat reputation wise but that will recover)

job_title: Data Engineering Analyst in Arlington, VA
pros:
Great people, great benefits (for the most part), a good variety of projects to work on and work to do, and good work-life balance for our industry (40 hrs a week) and paid overtime. Also, the company is pretty diverse which I like as a black person.

Also, for the people who will be joining the company soon. Something you should know is that you might get assigned to a project in a role that doesn't align w/ your title at all. If you are really passionate about what your role entails, you'll lay down the law w/ your HR partner. DO NOT let them push you into something you despise. That's how you end up leaving the company after your first year. You have to remember that they may be paid by management, but they work for you. Not the other way around. This worked really well for me, which is why I am loving it here. LOL

Also, I forgot to mention that I am on the federal side working w/ a federal client so I have no idea about the commercial side.
cons:
My only qualms are that we have no covid leave and our PTO is all lumped together. I get that the thinking in that it gives us more freedom to choose what to do with our time off. But you're actually creating a different problem. "Is taking a sick day or a mental day more important that a vacation day?" And 99 percent of the time I am gonna take that vacation day and disregard my health. If you want to watch out for both our mental and physical health we should at least get one additional hour in PTO.

Also, the project application and onboarding processes are kinda a mess for new joiners. B/c there is an HR rep and then there is another talent lead for the project and maybe portfolio that is looking for talent. As long as you keep your HR rep on a leash, things will work out for you. But that's not something taught to many new joiners, and why there's such a high turnover for new joiners.

review_title: Good company, good people, but stick to your guns
pros:
- Some seriously awesome people. A highly social, team-based culture which thrives on people being friendly and open to working together. 
- *Mostly* interesting client work 
- Very diverse workforce, but doesn't feel tokenistic. Lots of people from different cultural, educational and professional backgrounds. 
- Some incredibly smart people in the organisation that you can learn a lot from.
- If you like to learn, it's a good place to be. Have never felt discouraged from asking lots of questions.
- If you work hard and impress as an analyst, you can get promoted pretty quickly (under the 2 year guideline).
cons:
- Certain managers/senior managers exploit the eagerness of Analysts/Consultants and are ready to stamp their name on work that has been 100% done for them in order to help their promotion case (particularly true for extracurricular activities). 
- Too much expectation to be involved in extracurricular events in order to 'stand out'. Intellect and high performance in client work should be enough. 
- There are cliques, particularly amongst the Analyst - Manager levels and at times their behavior feels unbridled. You will know when you see it and my advice is to avoid, avoid, avoid. Focus on producing good client work, not sucking up to whoever has a healthy budget.

review_title: Consulting is just not for me
job_title: Data Science Consultant in Denver, CO
pros: Accenture has a great culture around diversity and women in STEM. I really appreciated that. There are clear processes that they commit to that make a great environment. There are also plenty of resources available, but a slight con is that there are actually so many that it's hard for a new person to navigate the resources without help.
cons: Everyone is working at 150% capacity. The nature of a consulting firm is that they're so competitive. Everyone around you is trying to perform better than you, which means if you weren't invited to the meeting where an item is being discussed- you don't know the information. I had a 55 hour week minimum between my core 40 hours for my client, 5 hours on admin related work because Accenture expects ridiculously planning on your career despite everything being up in the air (including when your next 3 month contract will be). I also had 10 hours per week of management training- which really translated to B2B sales, not growing people or helping them become better. Show up perfect or be devoured by colleagues. Very competitive atmosphere, no work life balance. You work with people from other countries on projects, which is good except they have no context for the industry (like American healthcare) and you end up either handing over a poor product or staying up late to redo the work because the analysts and interns didn't understand the assignment. Staff projects are bottom heavy as well- meaning you have too many green staff doing the work. Finally, Accenture has clients that have fallen out of favor due to their business models- you still have to help those large, disliked companies to succeed.

review_title: Decent starting point, but probably move on after a few years
pros:
- Graduate salary is competitive compared to other consultancies of similar size/reputation. 
- Great internal training/learning libraries, and a decent starting point for general consulting/professional skills. Name brand is a plus for CV.
- Potential for very interesting client work, if you are lucky, push really hard (at risk of burning bridges) or are that good in the field. ACN has many many clients spanning almost every industry.
- If you can deliver significantly higher than average results, and cozy up to the right people while doing that, then there is a potential to rise very very quickly, but these folks are 1/100.
cons:
- Salary competitiveness drops off at the higher you go, especially if your promotion track is slow. If you are below average rate of progression, IMHO you should leave *immediately*, unless you do not care about compensation at all. There is almost no reason to "wait" for it.
- My perception was that some branches of the company have greater perks/faster promotion paths. Could be particular regions trying to upskill/attract more talent in those branches. Lucky for you if you are in the good ones, bad if not. 
- Potential to be stuck with bad clients/uninteresting work, although this is not unique to Accenture. In my experience, I found it exceedingly difficult to roll off some longstanding projects.
- If you stagnate due to various reasons; not passionate about client/work, get too comfortable at a role, not friendly enough with your manager, or just unlucky; then you may get stuck at a career level for longer than you care for. 
- Not unique to ACN, but ability to network and sell yourself to upper management is very very important; it is not enough to perform good work and let that speak for itself. You have to "play the game" correctly, which is an actual (although arbitrary imo) skill that requires practice/learning.

review_title: Fake ''We care'' culture, no career progress opportunities and no flexibility for remote work
pros:
- good job for high school graduates with no experience to start off their career
- relaxed atmosphere and no real stress at work 
- and that's about it
cons:
- How things work in this company is the real money is made at top level management, when entry level workers get low wages, no benefits, bonuses or any real benefits
- There is no career progress, job is very dull and repetitive, hierarchy structure is very rigid, if you want to climb up the ladder to management you have to be ready to embrace the fake culture and propaganda
- Company advertises itself very well telling how it's a great place to work, when in reality they only offer a fake We Care program that offers no real help when employer truly needs it, there is mandatory wellness sessions monthly where you can chat with a coach, but when you have a real concern and reach out to HR or management they simply offer no solutions
- They also lack transparency and give no clear guidelines
- After 2 years of WFH they decided to offer no remote or hybrid options and give their workers no right to choose, either you go back to office or you are forced to quit
